topic.title: What's New
topic.shortdesc: The Couchbase SDK now includes support for Role-Based Access Control (RBAC), which is a feature of Couchbase Server 5.0, Enterprise Edition.

section.title: RBAC Support in the SDK
section.p: RBAC allows users to be granted specific privileges, in association with Couchbase Cluster-resources. Thus, one user may be granted only read access on a given bucket, while another user is granted both read and write access.
The principles and design-features of Couchbase RBAC are described in detail in the section Authorization. This information should be read by all developers.
The SDK now provides RBAC-support in the following areas:

ul.li:
Authentication: To access a resource within a Couchbase cluster, credentials must be passed. These consist of a username and (in most cases) password. Credentials must be recognized by Couchbase Server as corresponding to a user, defined either locally of externally (for example, by means of a centralized LDAP server). Each user is associated with one or more roles; and each role corresponds to a set of privileges. If the privileges permit the form of access requested by the user, access is duly granted; otherwise, it is denied.
This means that programs must now authenticate more frequently than before. The SDK therefore provides authenticator objects, which facilitate the authentication process.
A high-level description of authenticator-objects is provided in the section SDK Authentication. Code examples for Node.js, Java, Python, PHP, Go, C, and .NET are provided in the section Getting Started with the SDK.

User Management: Since resources can now only be accessed by defined users, user management-routines must frequently be performed. A user who is granted the Admin role can create other users, assign roles to them, and delete them from the system. The SDK provides APIs in support of these activities.
A high-level description of user management syntax is provided in the section SDK Authentication. Code examples for Node.js, Java, Python, PHP, Go, C, and .NET are provided in the section Getting Started with the SDK.
